p.s: John Worne uses a big variation of communicative strategies and stylistic devices in his artucle to convince the reader.
Even in the headline you can find a list, which is repeated in the first line can't, won't, don't (l. 1).
The author uses this three words to quickly summarise his impression of the britishBritish view for learning foreign languages.
These words right at the beginning of a article let the reader know what the text is about and which issue it's going to face.
We can see, that the author is not happy about this circumstance in line 12-15 at the latest.

He says Everyone speaks English in the world of buisnessbusiness (they don't) (l. 12-13), your iPhone will now translate road signs for you (but you may crash or choke on the roaming data charges) (l. 13-14) and the next generation of wearable tech will enable intercultural telepathy anyway (l. 14-15).
What we have here is a list of arguments that try to justify the decreasing number of students learning foreign languages.
The author gives counter arguments for the first two.
The last argument, which isn't realyreally a argument but more a ironic comment in the sense of these arguments, is just nonsense in the authorsauthor's eyes.
But like I said, after this list of arguments and counter arguments we know the authorsauthor's opinion on this topic.
